citations.narrative:
* There is a mixture of dirt, grease and other excreta accumulating on the interior fiberglass wall board in three
enclosures. Five dogs are in contact with the affected surfaces located in sheltered housing. The affected area covers
approximately 15 to 30 percent of the interior wall area. Cleaning of surfaces is necessary to prevent an accumulation of
excreta and other disease hazards. This indicates an unsanitary living condition exists that could lead to potential disease
or health risks. The applicant must ensure that hard surfaces with which the dogs come in contact must be spot cleaned
daily and sanitized in accordance with 3.11 (B) of this sub part to prevent accumulation of excreta and reduce disease
hazards.

* An estimated six inch in length sheet of tin insert in one enclosure containing two dogs has become detached. The insert
was jagged and sharp in appearance and was turned outwards towards the dogs. Jagged edges with sharp points could
cause potential injury. The applicant must ensure all primary enclosures be maintained in a manner that there are no
sharp points or edges that could injure the dogs.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class A license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by October 16, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.1(c)(3) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
* There is a mixture of dirt, grease and other excreta accumulating on the interior fiberglass wall board in three 
enclosures. Five dogs are in contact with the affected surfaces located in sheltered housing. The affected area covers 
approximately 15 to 30 percent of the interior wall area. Cleaning of surfaces is necessary to prevent an accumulation of 
excreta and other disease hazards. This indicates an unsanitary living condition exists that could lead to potential disease 
or health risks. The applicant must ensure that hard surfaces with which the dogs come in contact must be spot cleaned 
daily and sanitized in accordance with 3.11 (B) of this sub part to prevent accumulation of excreta and reduce disease 
hazards. 
3.6(a)(2)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
* An estimated six inch in length sheet of tin insert in one enclosure containing two dogs has become detached. The insert 
was jagged and sharp in appearance and was turned outwards towards the dogs. Jagged edges with sharp points could 
cause potential injury. The applicant must ensure all primary enclosures be maintained in a manner that there are no 
sharp points or edges that could injure the dogs. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class A license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by October 16, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
